text:
EFREN PENAFLORIDA: In 2009,
when the CNN Heroes met me

and the volunteers
pushing the carts,
people were laughing at us.
They would discourage us.

They would say that it's
just a waste of time.

ANDERSON COOPER: The CNN Hero of
the Year is Efren Penaflorida.
[cheering]

EFREN PENAFLORIDA: But after
CNN Heroes featured us,
it changed everything.

You are the change
that you dream,
as I am the change that I dream.

And collectively,
we are the change
that this world needs to be.
Mabuhay!
[cheering]

- Efren says the "Heroes"
recognition came at a time

when he needed support
more than ever.
- [chanting]

EFREN PENAFLORIDA:
After we were featured,

people were like,
you're doing a good job.
It changed everything.

It changed the perspective
of a lot of people.

- In a country where nearly
a quarter of the people

live below the poverty
line, Efren's story of hope

helped put a struggling
population on the map.

And as the world began
to focus on the plight

of children living
in poverty, more kids
got the chance to learn.

EFREN PENAFLORIDA: Whenever
we go from one community

to another community,
children were, like, swarming
around us, running towards us.

They were waiting
for us smiling.

And they really have
this hunger for learning.
[giggling]

- Today, Efren's
simple little cart

and a team of
passionate volunteers

have brought education to
an estimated 40,000 children
around the world.

Many of these kids were
sold into prostitution

or working in garbage dumps,
or had been coerced into gangs.

And Efren is helping them
learn and get back to school.

EFREN PENAFLORIDA: We
gather all the children.

We hold our programs
here for health care,
for feeding the children.

And we have activity like
school supplies giving.

We have regular
volunteers gathering,

providing them encouragement,
empowering them as much
as we can.
- Very good.

My life before was
really a miserable life.

I became a dropout
student, and then I've

been also in
prostitution, in child
prostitution, child labor.

The [inaudible] classroom
is not just a school for me,
but also a family for me.
- [inaudible].
JERIEMAY: [inaudible].

- This year, in one month
alone, Efren and his team

got more than 1,200
kids from the streets
back into the school system.
[clapping]

And on top of decreasing the
dropout rate in his hometown,

Efren has made waves
around the world.

He's received awards, done
television interviews,
and was the focus of a TV movie.

But Efren says
that more important

than the accolades
are the result
that his program has inspired.

EFREN PENAFLORIDA:
When we started

the organization, gangs,
street wars are very rampant.

We saw that there's a tremendous
decrease of the issues
of gangsters and gangs around.

And we are glad that we are
one of those people who help
in making the place better.

- Taking the pushcart
classroom to new levels,

Efren has recently teamed
up with the Department

of Education in the
Philippines, and

with other international
groups to replicate
the pushcart classroom.

EFREN PENAFLORIDA: The
[inaudible] classroom

here in the Philippines, it's
a symbol of hope and education.

We have counted 83 replications
all over the Philippines,

plus we have two abroad,
in Indonesia and in Kenya.
- One, two, three.

EFREN PENAFLORIDA: That crazy
idea have gone a long way.

It reaches thousands
of children,
and it touches their life.
- [inaudible].

EFREN PENAFLORIDA: We
believe that education
is a powerful tool.

It can make someone's
life become productive.
[screaming]

And it can really
change the world.

- With price money
from CNN Heroes,

Efren has also built new
educational facilities.

And in 2012, his group
opened up a new high school,

a solar-powered safe haven
for high school students

who've fallen
through the cracks.

EFREN PENAFLORIDA: The
factor of negative 60 is--
- [inaudible].
EFREN PENAFLORIDA: That's good.

We go from house to house
and try to get high school

students who still
want to go to school
but don't have the opportunity.

So we give them
a free education,

and help them graduate
in secondary education.
[indistinct chatter]

We're going to have our first
batch of graduates in 2018.

So we want to create a
higher education program

for these young people so that
they can fulfill their dreams,

and hopefully get a
decent job in the future.
[indistinct chatter]

Giving them an
opportunity and helping

them fulfilling their
dreams, that's for me more
rewarding than other things.

- Efren says his
CNN Hero colleagues
have also stayed close.

EFREN PENAFLORIDA:
x minus equals zero.

- When Typhoon Haiyan decimated
areas of the Philippines

in 2013, killing more
than 6,000 and causing

widespread destruction,
Efren mobilized

his own team to
help in Tacloban,
one of the hardest hit areas.

He also issued a rallying
cry to his fellow CNN Heroes.

EFREN PENAFLORIDA: I
contacted all my co-honorees,
and they responded.
Doc Hendley was there.

He was able to bring water
filters to each community.

Robin Lee was there also
to help pregnant women.

And when the three of us
met together in Tacloban,

we were like avengers
coming together
and help the community.
- Today, Efren is 35 years old.

He works on his
project full-time,
and teaches a math class.
And continues to push his cart.

EFREN PENAFLORIDA: I was
saved by this kind of program.

I was encouraged to continue
my education and love learning
and embrace it.

And that's what we are trying
to share with these children,

not to give up on their life,
not to give up on their dreams.

And so we believe that
education is a powerful tool

to make these children
become productive in life,

and help us help
change the world.
- [chanting]

EFREN PENAFLORIDA:
We're never too
young to give back to society.

And one is never too
ordinary to be a hero.
- Yay.
[clapping]

ANDERSON COOPER: Efren's work
has come a long way since we

met him, and kids
all over the world

are getting an education
because of one simple idea.

Do you know someone who
should be named a CNN Hero?
Tell us about them.

Nominations are now
open at cnnheroes.com.
